title: 112_hr6187
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cure for AIDS Act of 2012". The Congress finds and acknowledges certain facts. The Congress acknowledges the importance of finding a cure for AIDS to end the epidemic, the effectiveness of AIDS treatment in saving lives and preventing transmission, the need to expand access to treatment globally, the leading role of the National Institutes of Health in AIDS cure research, and the increasing importance of investing in complementary research areas. In 2010, an estimated 34 million people worldwide were living with HIV/AIDS, with 1.2 million infected in the United States. Every 9.5 minutes, a new HIV infection occurs in the US, totaling 2.7 million new infections in 2010. The Federal Government spent $27.7 billion on HIV/AIDS in fiscal year 2012, with a focus on services and treatment. A cure for AIDS could save millions of dollars and have a positive economic impact globally. In the United States, services and treatment for HIV/AIDS cost $15.6 billion. Recent discoveries have sparked optimism in finding a cure for AIDS, with researchers exploring various approaches like stem cells, gene therapy, and therapeutic vaccines. Establishment of HIV/AIDS Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program. The Secretary of Defense, through the Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program, will establish an accelerated research program in collaboration with various agencies to discover a cure for HIV/AIDS. Research will be highly targeted to address specific aspects for developing a cure. The Secretary of Defense, in collaboration with various agencies, will establish an accelerated research program through the Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program to discover a cure for HIV/AIDS. The research will focus on key scientific questions and priorities related to HIV persistence, immune system responses, virus levels, and interventions for infected individuals. The Secretary will coordinate with nonprofit entities dedicated to ending the AIDS epidemic through innovative research and with experience in AIDS cure research. The nonprofit entity selected will partner with the Secretary to establish research priorities for funded research. Annual reports on the Congressionally Directed Medical Research Program will be submitted to Congress. The Secretary will provide updates on the progress of the research program to Congress. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2013 through 2017.
